tags: shut up holly you're embarrassing yourself
summary: (1/3) Hey, I read your tags on wanting to know if causal viewers of Good Omens noticed the Aziraphale/Crowley relationship.  I...
question: (1/3) Hey, I read your tags on wanting to know if causal viewers of Good Omens noticed the Aziraphale/Crowley relationship.  I would say I went in very casual, but I’m also an ace lesbian so my Queer Relationship Sensors™ are probably a bit more finely calibrated than a straight viewer of the same casualness. I read the book one (1) day before I watched the show and It didn’t really come off as romantic to me. In contrast, the show always seemed like it was hinting at a romantic undertone…
answer:
(2/3) …but I didn’t think anything substantial was going to come of it. Until the string section playing over the long shot of Aziraphale’s expression in the church scene. It was such of confluence of Active Directorial Choices all at once that I was finally like “wait holy shit they’re Actually Doing This.” By the Somebody to Love scene I was already 100% on board.

(3/3) I think a lot of straight viewers not picking up on the relationship is more general obliviousness a la “Harold they’re lesbians” and ingrained skepticism about what sort of relationships a big TV production is likely or willing to portray, rather than active malice. Although that’s not to say there aren’t some homophobic fucks out there.

This sounds very On Point to me, yes! (and omg I also FLAILED over the music behind Zira in the Church! I can’t believe I forgot that… I guess it got overshadowed by ‘Somebody to Love’ later :p but yes, that was also a bit of a turning point moment for me where I personally reacted much like you describe - I think I even said OUT LOUD ‘oh my god they are getting romantic music wow!’)

My anxiety in the tags was really fuelled BY concern that viewers might still (be ABLE to) be oblivious though, rather than concern over people denying a queer reading out of malice. Because as much as malicious homophobes SUCK, any kind of violent, angry, active denial of a queer understanding of Zira and Crowley actually works to kinda support the fact the relationship is a love story, in a round about way - since I feel like there must surely be something significant there in order for people to feel a need to actively deny/reject it.

If lots of people honestly (and non-maliciously, as you say) simply DON’T SEE queer love/romance within the characters and their relationship though… idk… I just find that more concerning somehow? Makes me second guess myself (ie. worry that I’m seeing things as more queer than they are and that my judgement of media portrayals of queerness is therefore not especially trustworthy/reliable)… or fret that maybe the show wasn’t being clear/strong enough in its portrayal… which then gives me a touch of guilt, because the fact is I kinda ADORE the way the show portrayed Crowley and Zira’s love for each other, but if I start to fret that portrayal somehow wasn’t ‘good enough’ then I fret that my enjoyment of it is also somehow ‘not good enough’ and, blah, it’s a familiar twisted, largely irrational spiral of doubt!

I’ll get over it :P

(but yah, if more straight viewers could confirm they see the love/romance being portrayed in Zira and Crowley’s story that really would just make me feel a lot better about the show, myself and the world in general, k!)

summary: I mentioned this on twitter, but honestly, while a bit overwhelming, I really appreciate the sudden content for Good Omens and...
body:
I mentioned this on twitter, but honestly, while a bit overwhelming, I really appreciate the sudden content for Good Omens and the love people are having for the story

When I was in 7th grade I loved the story so much that I chose to do my end-of-the-year book report on it, and I played out the story with hand made paper puppets to all of my classmates (much to their horror). 

Crowley and War were my favorite characters so I spent extra time on their puppets and my favorite scene of all time was the Plant scene.
